body:
FYI @lmmentel who highlighted this.
FYI @miraep8 who recently thought about it in #2540 and #2458.
FYI @aiwalter, @TonyBagnall

My personal opinion is, 1. should go.
The requirement of 1. is coming from `sklearn`, the rationale being that calling `fit` multiple times, and possibly `set_params` in-between, should be possible and result in the same state as after the last `fit` call.

This has, however, some negative consequences for the user which are discussed at the start of this issue: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1798

`sklearn` has no choice in this imo, since there is no "boilerplate" layer and all the checks etc need to be implemented by a user every ime they write an estimator.
We, however, do have a choice - we can call parameter setting and checking logic from the layer between `fit` and `_fit`.

Like this: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2562
(https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1798 proposes a more extreme variant that might be overkill)

We still would be `sklearn` compatible, since the external logic would be indistinguishable.

There is one - positive! - exception:
with this, the user receives feedback at *specification* of an invalid estimator, not just at `fit` which is later.
This would be in line with the principle "give feedback on invalid input as early as possible", and `sklearn` is *not*  in line with that!

issue.title: [ENH] Differencer NA handling - "fill zero" parameter

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
From a pair programming session with @lbventur (at the community meetup).

This PR solves #2478, it upgrades `Differencer` with NA handling parameter `na_handling`, which allows, besides the two current behaviours, a third behaviour `fill_zero` that fills zero.

This parameter replaces the boolean `drop_na` parameter, and adds deprecation with replacement at 0.13.0, and move to a `fill_zero` default.

Why is the `fill_zero` parameter a better default? It results in a "same index" and "no NA" condition at the end, which is the most compatible out of the alternatives when used in a pipeline. See also discussion (and user frustration) here: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2452 and here: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2451

rename.from: [ENH] design - init, parameter check, dynamic tags - conflicting requirements
rename.to: [ENH] design - init, parameter check, dynamic tags - conflicting interface specification requirements

rename.from: [ENH] design - init, parameter check, dynamic tags - conflicting interface specification requirements
rename.to: [ENH] design - init, parameter check, dynamic tags - conflicting interface requirements

body:
Out of curiosity - are dynamic tags a relative new thing (ie essentially only used in `MultiplexForecaster`?) or is it a more wide spread thing.  (I am more familiar with `MultiplexForecaster` at the moment... haven't directly seen it other places, but thought I would ask!)  If it is only really seen in `MultiplexForecaster` - then as I mentioned in #2458 it is possible to not dynamically set tags in `MultiplexForecaster` (at least it is not necessary for `fit` to work)-in fact #2570 provides a way to do this by bypassing the fit call on `MultiplexForecaster`.  Though as #2570 stands it doesn't completely solve the other other issue you mentioned in relation to dynamically setting tags:

>However, I see a problem with retrieval and querying, so while tempting I fear this might not work.
The problem arises because the tags on the outside would no longer be "true", so they cannot be relied upon anymore for giving correct answers about properties.
>
>For example, let's assume a user asking a pipeline "can you work with multivariate data"? The multiplexer would give the wrong answer.
It would also give the wrong answer if you further put the multiplexer in a pipeline, to the other parts of the pipeline that now wrap the multiplexer.
Another example, let's say we loop through forecaster instances in testing. We want to pass multivariate data to all forecasters that claim they are multivariate and check they do not raise the error. The multiplexer would then fail the test, because the inner forecaster cannot deal with the multivariate data, but the test would think that it should be able to.

But.... I think it could be an easy change for the new delegator approach to solve this problem as well!!! (If you think it is worth looking into!)

> is it a more wide spread thing.

It is fairly wide-spread, it happens in composites. Search for `clone_tags` or `set_tag` to find more instances.

> But.... I think it could be an easy change for the new delegator approach to solve this problem as well!!! (If you think it is worth looking into!)

That might solve it for the delegator, but not for the other composites?

Example: in classification, you want to know whether a classifier can deal with missing values If not, the base class raises an error message. For a pipeline, that depends on properties of its pipeline elements, namely whether they can either deal with missing values, or whether there is one element that removes missing values.

@aiwalter, you commented on a couple PR on content of the `__init__` - do you want to add something here?
This is precisely the topic...

Since it is not the first time the *same* question regarding design surfaces we need a clearer design direction on this. As much as am I'm not happy with all the design choices of sklearn api it is at least very clear on what it takes to compatible an why. Not to mention test of the years. We should take this opportunity to define the api design principles for sktime and wither follow sklearn fully, partially or come up with our own api design.

My personal opinion would go towards adopting sklearn fully with all it's tradeoffs since that is the _de facto_ standard.

> My personal opinion would go towards adopting sklearn fully with all it's tradeoffs since that is the de facto standard.

I think that´s not possible since we are a package for time series and sklearn is not. So there is some degree we need to depart from sklearn. "adopting sklearn fully" has a nice ring to it but what is there to "adopt"? The supervised regression interface, e.g., do you want to turn the forecasters into sklearn compatible supervised regressors? Probably not. So, would appreciate this spelled out more concretely.

issue.title: [ENH] General Delegator Design Discussion

labels.name: implementing framework
labels.description: Implementing frameworks for new learning tasks

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
### Overview:

This issue is intended to be a spot for a design discussion for how to implement a new more general delegation functionality per a suggestion from @fkiraly .

To give some context for the issue at hand - many of the composite classes related to multiple estimator testing/comparison - e.g. `MultiplexForecaster` behave *like* a wrapper where most of their forecasting functionality is delegated to a wrapped forecaster. In implementing `MultiplexTransformer` it became clear a more general delegation functionality (that also extended to transformers) would be useful. And that the current delegation approach seemed to have some issues that required dynamic tag setting/might make it hard to apply to BaseGridSearch (which it would also be useful, as it has a very important `_fit` class).  #2570 is an attempt to solve this problem, however I think it has some design issues, so thought opening it up to move discussion might be very useful!

### Summary of the Two Approaches:

(*there are of course more than 2 ways to solve this problem, but this summarizes the approach I have implemented and the mixin approach already in place.  Also, just an attempt to  give a high level sense of what these two approaches are doing/how they differ, but I may have left something important out - so please chime in if I did. *)

##### Current approach via the mixin (as it was implemented):
- Have a `DelegatedForecaster` class each class requiring delegation inherits from (as a "mixin")
- This class overwrites all the underscore methods (eg `_fit()`, `_predict()` etc) so that they are called on the delegated forecaster instead.
- This means the original functions are called on all wrapped estimators - which can have various issues (namely we now need to dynamically set the tags of the composite classes so that when we call `fit()` on them we accept inputs. 
- The solution to this is to add some logic to `__init__`, and have a `reset()` function that is called at the start of each call to `fit()`. 
- The advantage of this approach is only the estimator actually in need of having a delegation ability is exposed to the delegation logic by inheriting from the mixin. 

##### Proposed new approach via the decorator (as it was implemented):
- Add a decorator to all the main functions in `BaseEstimator` (eg `fit()`, `predict()` etc) which will delegate that function to the wrapped estimator if one is provided.
- Add an attribute to store the name of the attribute storing the estimator these functions should be delegated to. Defaults to `None` so estimators that do not delegate should not be affected. 
- This approach has a disadvantage in that all `BaseEstimator`'s now have delegation logic attached to them even though many of them might not need it. 
- Because `fit()` is no longer being called on the "main estimator" we now no longer need to dynamically set tags, (at least not to get `fit()` to work).  This makes sense to me at least.
- But because `fit()` is no longer called on the main estimator, we now need a way to copy over certain attributes to the main estimator (e.g. `_y`, `_fh`, `_is_fitted` and `_cutoff`), so we need an additional functionality in the decorator which takes care of copying over these attributes from the wrapped estimator to the main estimator.  - we keep track of the names of the estimator to copy over in a new attribute. 

Note, in my mind the main design advantages/disadvantages of each approach actually don't come from either using a delegator/mixin, but rather how each are implemented (in my mind). Taking this into account, I propose a hybrid solution: 

##### Hybrid Solution: 
- Use a mixin (Personally I think the mixin would work well here, as I think it is the easiest way to make sure only the classes which need delegation functionality get it.)
- Give the mixin has an attribute called `_funcs_to_delegate` which will include the names of the functions to be delegated ie [`fit`, `predict`,...] etc.  This will be nice because certain functions might not want to delegate all functions (ie `BaseGridSearch` which for the most part is a great candidate for delegation doesn't actually work well if you delegate `fit()`, and having the ability to control which functions get delegated is useful.)
- We will then use a decorator to wrap all these functions based on the function names provided. (@ltsaprounis has to do something similar in his mock estimator stuff/I like the way he did it so I would plan to do it similarly here). 

Note - this would stick with delegating the non-underscore classes, which I think is a good idea. We will then still need to copy over certain attributes from the fitted data to the wrapped estimator. (And I would probably do this in a similar way as I did before).

issue.title: [ENH] `set_params` to call `reset`, to comply with `sklearn` parameter interface assumptions

labels.name: implementing framework
labels.description: Implementing frameworks for new learning tasks

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This PR modifies `set_params` to also execute a full `reset`, which calls any `__init__` code such as dynamic tag setting.

Also adds parameter inspection related class methods to `BaseObject`:
* `get_param_names` - retrieves list of parameter names
* `get_param_defaults` - retrieves name/default dict of parameter defaults

Why `set_params` should execute a `reset`: @aiwalter pointed me to this specification document in `sklearn` which makes a key interface assumption explicit, namely that the result of `set_params` must be the same as `__init__(**self.get_params())`.

Since `sktime` may have some `__init__` content besides `self` writes (in deviation from `sklearn` due to varia discussed in #2573), we can ensure consistency here by calling `reset` from `set_params`.
This relates to discussion in, and also partially addresses https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2573 .

As a secondary effect of this, the `test_set_params` test was failing in instances where parameter related logic was present in `__init__`, e.g., cloning estimators to `component_name_`, due to testing logic in `sklearn`'s `check_set_params` which was called from `test_set_params`. The reason for that is that `sklearn`'s test would overwrite parameters with `np.inf` etc to mimic a change, which is fine in `sklearn` since it strictly has no logic in `__init__`. However, `sktime` estimators may have logic, such as dynamic tag setting, which therefore would break the `set_params` now identical with `__init__`.

Therefore, the `test_set_params` test was changed from overwriting with `np.inf` etc, to overwriting with values from other test cases as available through `get_test_params` and `get_param_defaults` (needed for full set), which ensures validity.

body:
From discussion with @aiwalter today:

we agreed on that "`__init__` has no content" is a side artefact of the "no boilerplate layer" design in `scikit-learn`, it is, in parts, an internal (implementer facing) requirement.

The *really important* requirement is the user/external facing one, "`set_params` leaves the same state as `__init__` would", also see PR https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2835.

So, going forward, we will adopt the latter, possibly restricting the things that should be in `__init__` (but without restricting it to "nothing"). I'll make a PR that updates the extension templates.

issue.title: [ENH] parameter checking and move of `super.__init__` in extension templates

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This PR updates extension templates to the decision in https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2573.

That is, `__init__` can now contain additional logic of parameter checking kind, or tag setting, but it must be after the call to `super.__init__`.

body:
This PR implements this: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/3010
(I think? please comment)
